The game that defined the FPS genre for me, Unreal Tournament is still a well-played powerhouse of deadly weaponry and hyper-speed action. The sheer adreneline rush this game instills emerses the player in a far future galaxy brimming with violence all for the chance of becoming the champion.  Vast amounts of arenas in which you can gib and telefrag your enemies are available, and a very large community grants a plethora of modded content and extra arenas. Apply mods to your game for even more crazy speed, extra guns, instagib, or other challenging, and game changing modes. Multiple game styles from deathmatch to capture the flag are sure to bring a welcome abundance of blood and entertainment to your day.

Unreal Tournament is an undying classic. I first started playing this when it first came out and have not stopped since. While it has no storyline to speak of, it does have unrelenting action and infinite replayability. Unreal Tournament is just what the name says. A bloody tournament with all manner of unreal, fun weapons and arenas. The AI are actually very skilled (unless you set them to a lower difficulty). And playing with fellow humans can make the game intensely challenging and exciting.  What are the cons? Well, like any game that's about a decade old, its graphics are outdated. Any other fault is so minute it's not even worth mentioning.

What can be said about this classic?   Rating: 10/10 Pros:  *Graphics that still stand up to the test of time *Intense gameplay *Stylish art direction *Dark sci-fi setting *Character customization - in an FPS?! *One of the best game soundtracks ever Cons: *Gameplay can drag at times *Single player is a bit on the short side *Those who don't want to deal with multiplayer may not find themselves entirely supported  All in all, this game is a classic for a reason. Buy it now while it's cheap and get hours of enjoyment.

MONSTER KILL-IL-IL  Come and relive FPS history. For me, this is the first FPS I ever played so I enjoy it maybe more than the average person. However, this is a truly great no-frills arena FPS and if you've never experienced such a thing and are tired of all the CoD tripe then I highly reccomend it. If you're the kinda person who likes casual FPS and looking at pretty graphics... well I'd still try it but it's probably not for you. XD  Pros:  + Balance - some weapons are more powerful than others, but what really counts is SKILL  + Gametypes - DM, TDM, Domination, CTF, Assault, and more  + Level Design - they just don't make 'em like this anymore  + Amount of Levels - more than enough to keep you from getting bored for a long time  + Singleplayer Tournament - climb the ladder in different gametypes with pretty decent team AI when commanded properly  + Multiplayer - Stille active after all these years, and doesn't require a silly gamespy account  Cons:  - Dated Graphics  - Takes some tweaking to get your mouse functioning properly (more on this below)  *Mouse Setup Guide* 1. Grab the Direct3D9 Renderer from   here   [www.cwdohnal.com] . 2. Put D3D9Drv.dll and D3D9Drv.int in your 'Steam\steamapps\common\Unreal Tournament\System' folder 3. Use your graphics card control panel to disable v-sync 4. Use your graphics card control panel to limit your fps to your monitors refresh rate (i.e. 60Hz monitor = 60fps cap) this prevents the game from running in superfast mode. If you aren't sure of your monitors refresh rate, just cap it at 60. A useful program for doing this with Nvidia cards is   Nvidia Inspector   [www.guru3d.com] . 5. As always, make sure you have Windows built-in mouse acceleration disabled. Go to your control panel>Mouse Properties>Pointer Options and uncheck 'Enhance pointer precision' because in reality this hinders your precision by applying OS-level mouse acceleration! This last step is essential for all FPS games.

The first game of the UT saga, it is rightfully considered a 'father' to first-person shooters, being a pre-21st Century experience that never fails to impress (even on its surreal graphics). The atmosphere is eerie but invigorating, the sort of thing that keeps it a game to be played again and again; augmented by the evocative soundtracks that I often play on YouTube for the sake of reminiscing on other games. The gaming aspect binds well with the atmosphere too, on levels from Deathmatches to Capture-The-Flags: the 'Unreal Tournament' name is a critical review in itself.

Unfortunately, the devastation left by the nuclear bomb known as Half-Life sent the likes of both Epic Games and Id Software back into the stone age, back to the primitive era of online deathmatch FPS games. It would be some time before they both recovered fully. In the meantime, Epic dedicated themselves to sharpening UT's weaponry, level design, and FPS mechanics to as fine a point as physically possible in 1999, successfully creating the world's most technically advanced FPS trebuchet.

This is the best multiplayer deathmatch shooter ever, period. There are so many great memories of the online mayhem. This was a big part of the golden era of online shooters. This was back when PC online shooters were a gentleman's game, absent the 12 year old trash talk and every match ended with a 'gg'  The music, attitude, and gameplay all mesh perfectly. It's not the belle of the ball graphically, but it passes off fine at high resolutions. You're reminded the age of this game with the omission of reload and having to remap the movement keys from arrow to WASD. This is a lost gameplay mechanic today. Conserving ammo for quality shots, instead of reloading every second you're behind cover.  To get it running on widescreen resolutions you'll have to modify the 'unrealtournament.ini' file located in the Unreal Tournament \ System folder.  FullscreenViewportX=1920 FullscreenViewportY=1080 FOVAngle Degrees=107

Still as much fun today as it was back when it was first released. Truly a game that stands the tests of time.  A frantic, fast-paced FPS that's filled with action. High game speed, little to no cover, and very few places to hide. The weapons are quite unique and with each weapon having 2 firing modes, the different playstyles one can adopt are plenty. A game that is still a lot of fun to play competitive against your friends in.  The amount of game modes offered are decent enough, considering its age. Most are pretty standard game modes that one usually expects from games with competitive multiplayer, but it does offer some that stand out such as Assault. It also has a fair amount of maps, most of which are very memorable and iconic. There are also a lot of fan made custom maps that are easy to put into the game.

Long before CoD and BF franchises existed..  The golden age of FPS games: Wolfenstein, Doom, Quake, and Unreal. Unreal eventually added multiplayer, becoming Unreal Tournament '99.  These games had no kill streaks, no customizable classes, no '$20 dlc', no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. You had to have skill to win.  Think you're good? Set the AI to inhuman (or godlike if you want a real spanking). This game doesn't forgive mistakes. (If you're insane, enable instagib.)  (I have admin'd a few UT servers off and on.. over the years.)  TLDR: A real FPS game. (Worth it!) CoD/BF newbies need not apply.
